speaker: LEAR
text: Let me not stay a jot for dinner. Go get it ready.

speaker: LEAR
text: How now, what art thou?

speaker: KENT
text: A man, sir.

speaker: LEAR
text: What dost thou profess? What wouldst thou with

speaker: LEAR
text: us?

speaker: KENT
text: I do profess to be no less than I seem, to serve

speaker: KENT
text: him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that

speaker: KENT
text: is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says

speaker: KENT
text: little, to fear judgment, to fight when I cannot

speaker: KENT
text: choose, and to eat no fish.

speaker: LEAR
text: What art thou?

speaker: KENT
text: A very honest-hearted fellow, and as poor as the

speaker: KENT
text: King.

speaker: LEAR
text: If thou be’st as poor for a subject as he’s for a

speaker: LEAR
text: king, thou art poor enough. What wouldst thou?

speaker: KENT
text: Service.

speaker: LEAR
text: Who wouldst thou serve?

speaker: KENT
text: You.

speaker: LEAR
text: Dost thou know me, fellow?

speaker: KENT
text: No, sir, but you have that in your countenance

speaker: KENT
text: which I would fain call master.

speaker: LEAR
text: What’s that?

speaker: KENT
text: Authority.

speaker: LEAR
text: What services canst do?

speaker: KENT
text: I can keep honest counsel, ride, run, mar a

speaker: KENT
text: curious tale in telling it, and deliver a plain message

speaker: KENT
text: bluntly. That which ordinary men are fit for I

speaker: KENT
text: am qualified in, and the best of me is diligence.

speaker: LEAR
text: How old art thou?

speaker: KENT
text: Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing,

speaker: KENT
text: nor so old to dote on her for anything. I have years

speaker: KENT
text: on my back forty-eight.

speaker: LEAR
text: Follow me. Thou shalt serve me—if I like thee

speaker: LEAR
text: no worse after dinner. I will not part from thee

speaker: LEAR
text: yet.—Dinner, ho, dinner!—Where’s my knave, my

speaker: LEAR
text: Fool? Go you and call my Fool hither.

speaker: LEAR
text: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?

speaker: OSWALD
text: So please you—

speaker: LEAR
text: What says the fellow there? Call the clotpole

back.

text: the world’s asleep.

speaker: LEAR
text: How now? Where’s that mongrel?

speaker: KNIGHT
text: He says, my lord, your daughter is not well.

speaker: LEAR
text: Why came not the slave back to me when I

speaker: LEAR
text: called him?

speaker: KNIGHT
text: Sir, he answered me in the roundest manner,

speaker: KNIGHT
text: he would not.

speaker: LEAR
text: He would not?

speaker: KNIGHT
text: My lord, I know not what the matter is, but to

speaker: KNIGHT
text: my judgment your Highness is not entertained

speaker: KNIGHT
text: with that ceremonious affection as you were wont.

speaker: KNIGHT
text: There’s a great abatement of kindness appears as

speaker: KNIGHT
text: well in the general dependents as in the Duke

speaker: KNIGHT
text: himself also, and your daughter.

speaker: LEAR
text: Ha? Sayst thou so?

speaker: KNIGHT
text: I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be

speaker: KNIGHT
text: mistaken, for my duty cannot be silent when I think

speaker: KNIGHT
text: your Highness wronged.

speaker: LEAR
text: Thou but remembrest me of mine own conception.

speaker: LEAR
text: I have perceived a most faint neglect of late,

speaker: LEAR
text: which I have rather blamed as mine own jealous

speaker: LEAR
text: curiosity than as a very pretense and purpose of

speaker: LEAR
text: unkindness. I will look further into ’t. But where’s

speaker: LEAR
text: my Fool? I have not seen him this two days.

speaker: KNIGHT
text: Since my young lady’s going into France, sir,

speaker: KNIGHT
text: the Fool hath much pined away.

speaker: LEAR
text: No more of that. I have noted it well.—Go you

speaker: LEAR
text: and tell my daughter I would speak with her.

speaker: LEAR
text: Go you call hither my Fool.

speaker: LEAR
text: O you, sir, you, come you hither, sir. Who am I, sir?

speaker: OSWALD
text: My lady’s father.

speaker: LEAR
text: “My lady’s father”? My lord’s knave! You whoreson

speaker: LEAR
text: dog, you slave, you cur!

speaker: OSWALD
text: I am none of these, my lord, I beseech your

speaker: OSWALD
text: pardon.

speaker: LEAR
text: Do you bandy looks with me, you rascal?

speaker: OSWALD
text: I’ll not be strucken, my lord.

speaker: KENT
text: Nor tripped neither, you base

speaker: KENT
text: football player?

speaker: KENT
text: differences. Away, away. If you will measure your

speaker: KENT

speaker: KENT
text: you wisdom? So.

speaker: LEAR
